title: Vigil highlights workplace safety issue
text:
Vigil highlights workplace safety issue 
Sunday 9 Aug 2015 1:20 p.m. 
Health and safety (iStock) 
The issue of workplace safety is being highlighted by a vigil in the forestry town of Tokoroa where 297 crosses are being placed. 
The crosses represent lives lost at work since the 2010 Pike River coal mine tragedy. 
One cross is for Charles Finlay, 45, who was killed on July 19, 2013 at a forestry work site in the Taumata Forest, Kinleith. 
His wife Maryanne, who organised the vigil on the corner of Balmoral Drive and Arawa Cres on Sunday, spoke about the impact the death has had on her and her three children. 
"Our family won't be normal for a long time," she said. 
The vigil is being held as the health and safety reform bill makes its way through parliament. 
It's the biggest shake-up in workplace rules and regulations in 20 years and was drafted in the aftermath of the Pike disaster but critics say it's been watered down. 
The government says it's struck the right balance between safe workplaces and unnecessary red tape. 
The forest industry is improving its safety performance. 
According to the Council of Trade Unions the forestry accident rate has dropped by 60 percent and there has been one forestry accident in 15 months.
